document.masterDocTitle: A new Afrotropical genus Monocentroptilum gen. n. (Ephemeroptera: Baetidae: Protopatellata)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new Afrotropical genus Monocentroptilum gen. n. (Ephemeroptera: Baetidae: Protopatellata)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Centroptilum badium
Kopelke 1980a : 113
(♂ and ♀ imago); Kopelke 1980b: 301 (eggs).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Crassabwa badia
: LugO-OrtiZ & McCafferty 1996b: 238.

Material examined. UGANDA , Kanungu district , river Munyaga just downstream Bwindi National Park, 0º58'40"S , 29º37'15"E , 23–26.VII.2007 , coll. N. Kluge: 3 L-S-I ♂ , 1 S-I ♂ , 1 L-S/I ♂ , 2 L-S ♂ , 6 L-S-I ♀ , 5 L-S ♀ , 59 larvae ; river Ishasha downstream Bwindi National Park, 0º51'S , 29º39'30"E , 14.VII.2007 , coll. N. Kluge: 3 larvae ; Kasese district , Rwenzory mountains, tributary of river Mubuku upstream Ruboni, 0º21'N , 30º02'E , 28.VII– 6.VIII.2007 , coll. N. Kluge: 1 larva.

FIGURES 40–43.

subSubSection.paragraph:
STRUCTURE. General appearance, including shape of head, thorax, legs, abdomen and caudalii ( Fig. 1 ) similar to that of
Baetis
s.str.

Pronotum with lateral margins rounded ( Fig. 23 ). Mesonotum with 2 pairs of small protuberances: one pair near posterior margin between protoptera, another in front of them ( Figs 1 , 23 , 28 ). Dorsal side of head, pronotum and mesonotum with minute triangular setae, each narrow at base and sharply widened apically ( Fig. 24 , 28 ); elongated setae of the same type form dense bunches on top of each protuberance of mesonotum ( Figs 25 , 28 ).

All tergalii I–VII obliquely truncate in such a manner that costal margin seems shorter than anal margin; both costal and anal margins sclerotized ( Figs 1, 3 , 10–16 ); in distal part sclerotized and non-sclerotized margins with few seta-bearing denticles ( Fig. 17 ); tergalial tracheae invisible (very narrow, short and colorless); tergalius I narrow, tergalii III–VII progressively decrease in size.
RESPIRATORY MOVEMENTS. Absent; tergalii unable to make rhythmical movements; being placed to stagnant water, larva cannot live for a long time.

Subimago .
CUTICULAR COLORATION. Pronotum brown; mesonotum brown with contrasting colorless medioparapsidal suture; thoracic pleura and sterna partly brown, partly colorless ( Fig. 32 ). Shape of postsubalar sclerite as seen in Fig. 43 . Wings brown due to brown rings around base of each microtrichion (as in Kluge 2012b : Fig. 22 ). Legs with brown markings on femur and base of tibia ( Figs 37–39 ). Abdomen nearly unicolor brown; each tergum with pair of slightly darker brown triangular markings; in male sternum IX and gonostyli lighter than other sterna and terga. Cerci colorless.

Imago, male .
Described by Kopelke (1980a) .

STRUCTURE. Turban eyes narrow and cylindrical ( Figs 32–33 , 42 ). Anteronotal protuberance pointed in lateral view ( Figs 32 , 42 ). Hind wing of the «
Centroptilum
- type »: narrow, with 2 longitudinal veins, with single hooked costal projection ( Fig. 41 ). On middle and hind leg tarsus less than ½ of tibia length, with apical spine on 1 st and 2nd tarsomeres (initial 2nd and 3rd tarsomeres) (as in Fig. 39 ).

Male genitals ( Figs 44–52 ): Unistyligers with ventral surface sclerotized and pigmented except proximalmedian angle ( Figs 46 , 49 ); median styligeral sclerite present, elongate ( Figs 46 , 49, 51 ). Median styligeral muscle wide, attached to median styligeral sclerite and to unistyligers ( Figs 46 , 51 ). 1 st segment of gonostylus short and thick, with inner margin irregularly crumpled ( Figs 46 , 49, 50, 52 ). 3rd (distal) segment elongate ( Figs 46 , 48, 52 ). Gonovectes pointed, with apices sharply bent caudally and split at place of gonoduct attachment ( Figs 46 , 48, 50 ). Median part of penial bridge concave ( Figs 46 , 50 ).

Eggs .
Oval, 0.11 mm length. Chorion with poorly expressed net-like relief with small cells ( Figs 53–58 ).

AbbreviatiOns: 1–3, segments Of gOnOstylus; gv, gOnOvectis; m.sg, median sternO-styligeral muscle; pgs, larval prOtOgOnOstylus; usg, unistyliger.

FIGURES 48–52. Male imaginal genitals
Of Monocentroptilum badium
. 48–49, specimen with prOtracted gOnOvectes: 48, with fOcus On internal parts, including gOnOvectes; 49, with fOcus On ventral surface, including unistyligers and median styligeral sclerite; 50–51, specimen with retracted gOnOvectes: 50, with fOcus On gOnOvectes and penial bridge; 51, with fOcus On median styligeral sclerite and median sternO-styligeral muscle; 52, gOnOstyli.

subSubSection.paragraph: Dimensions. Fore wing length (and body length) 3.5–4.5 mm.

Distribution.
Congo
and Uganda .

Collecting place. Most part of larvae were collected in the river Munyaga 4 km upstream of the place where this river is served as the state boundary between Uganda and
Democratic Republic of the Congo
. Upstream of the collecting place, this small river runs in a dark forest of the Bwindi National Park; at this area its water is cold, mayflies are abundant, but their species diversity is limited, with domination of
Tricorythus exophthalmus Kluge 2010
. Just downstream from the forest, this river runs by opened space in the village; here mayfly fauna has maximum species diversity and includes
M. badium
. Downstream from this place Munyaga continues to run by opened space among fields, its water becomes warmer, and mayfly fauna is poor.
